Based on basic linear model (1)

Based on the LD model, for a +1 degree C increase in regional average temperature; interpreted as cumulative effect on total expenditures. Authors warn that this value is implausibly high; using 2009 as the final year of the data
Non-discounted change due to warming. Includes both cut and full data estimates. 2020s is interpreted as average of 2011-2040.
Non-discounted change due to warming. Includes both cut and full data estimates. 2020s is interpreted as average of 2011-2040.
Non-discounted change due to warming. Includes both cut and full data estimates. 2020s is interpreted as average of 2011-2040.
Non-discounted change due to warming. Includes both cut and full data estimates. 2020s is interpreted as average of 2011-2040.
Lower bound of the estimated savings. The 2020s is interpreted as 2025
Upper bound of the estimated savings. The 2020s is interpreted as 2025
Roughly half of savings from 2000-2020s had accrued by end of 2000s. This is calculated as half of the lower bound. The end of 2000s is interpreted as 2009
Roughly half of savings from 2000-2020s had accrued by end of 2000s. This is calculated as half of the upper bound. The end of 2000s is interpreted as 2009

Non-linear and population-weighted estimate for the Russia-wide impact of a 1째C increase in annual temperature is a decrease of 2.6 % in regional budget expenditures in real terms. This is assigned to 2010.

From Fixed Effects estimation using mid-term climate with full data; Effect of Temperature on Total Expenditures. The analysis employs econometric techniques on a sub-national panel dataset for Russia (1995-2009)

From Fixed Effects estimation using mid-term climate with data excluding 5% of both tails from temperature and precipitation; Effect of Temperature on Total Expenditures. The analysis employs econometric techniques on a sub-national panel dataset for Russia (1995-2009)

From Fixed Effects estimation using mid-term climate with full data; Effect of Temperature on Housing Expenditures. The analysis employs econometric techniques on a sub-national panel dataset for Russia (1995-2009)

From Fixed Effects estimation using mid-term climate with data excluding 5% of both tails from temperature and precipitation; Effect of Temperature on Housing Expenditures. The analysis employs econometric techniques on a sub-national panel dataset for Russia (1995-2009)

From Fixed Effects estimation using mid-term climate with full data; Effect of Precipitation on Housing Expenditures. The analysis employs econometric techniques on a sub-national panel dataset for Russia (1995-2009)

From Fixed Effects estimation using mid-term climate with data excluding 5% of both tails from temperature and precipitation; Effect of Precipitation on Housing Expenditures. The analysis employs econometric techniques on a sub-national panel dataset for Russia (1995-2009)

From Long-difference (LD) estimations with additional temperature variables, full data and data excluding 5 % of both tails from temperature and precipitation variables; Effect of Precipitation on Total Expenditures. The analysis employs econometric techniques on a sub-national panel dataset for Russia (1995-2009)
